stream_context.summary: Kaze live-builds a new ‘space plantation’ side-section for Return to Yoshi’s Island, experimenting with bumpers, glowing springs, crop models, water tanks and readability tweaks while discussing crashes, performance on real N64 hardware and broader design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: The new area’s core mechanic is using bumper-springs to traverse a plantation layout; half the section is still unbuilt.
development_findings.quote: So the idea with this area here, you use these bumpers to get around the plantation.

development_findings.summary: World name tentatively set to “Cosmic Colony”; Kaze is adding glowing outlines on platforms and signs to reduce visual noise and guide the player.
development_findings.quote: I think this level now has a little bit of the sauce… now it has a bit of sauce.

development_findings.summary: Low-poly ‘glow’ crops will be arranged in neat rows; he plans to reuse the neon rim shader for them.
Springs are being redesigned to look metallic, match palette and remove casino-style rainbow scrolls.
Backward Long Jump (BLJ) is still possible but currently crashes due to an infinite loop in custom BLJ code; Kaze must add explicit support.
development_findings.quote: It sometimes crashes, and I don’t know why… I guess I have to explicitly support it somehow.

development_findings.summary: Real N64 test shows 43 FPS with current plant density; render distance and draw calls will be tuned to keep target performance.
development_findings.quote: It doesn’t like all these plants here.

development_findings.summary: Uses Fast64; uploads builds directly to an N64 flashcart; employs a skybox cube that follows the camera at adjustable percentages to save memory and overdraw.
Design rule: build gameplay first, then craft story beats around finished levels.
development_findings.quote: I think it’s better to just put together some gameplay first, and then plan the story around the gameplay you have.

development_findings.summary: Water tanks will use a CPU-generated, ultra-slow ripple texture to simulate still water; current UV-scroll animation deemed too lively.
Post-game ideas include adding Luigi and sandbox freedoms (e.g., room cap anywhere, faster enemies) rather than traditional extra levels.

context_findings.summary: Kaze wants RTYI to stand alone as a ‘real game’ rather than a curiosity for Mario 64 fans.
context_findings.quote: I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also playable as a normal game without the context of Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: He proposes a 30-day, 12-16 h per-day dev-stream where donations extend the schedule—money would go to his own income, not charity.
context_findings.quote: The goal… is to make a full major Mario 64 hack… For my bank account. I’m not doing 30 days of working 15 hours a day for charity.

context_findings.summary: Streaming fatigues him; rapid-fire viewer questions feel like an interrogation.
context_findings.quote: Guys, why do you ask me so many questions today? That’s my least favorite thing to happen ever.

context_findings.summary: Philosophically unbothered by AI replacing creative tasks; sees backlash as existential insecurity.
context_findings.quote: You’re just experiencing existential regrets because the machine can do things that you thought were making you special.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledges Nintendo takedown history (Missing Link) but plans to open-source RTYI after release.
context_findings.quote: I’m planning to open source this game anyway, so there’s little point in leaking it.

context_findings.summary: Childhood resentment toward Mario Tennis influences avoidance of Tennis references in RTYI.
Daily meetings (e.g., Banjo-Kazooie × Mario 64 project) limit his ability to stream consistently.

biobak.summary: Most placeholder visuals Kaze builds will be reworked by Biobak during a later art pass.
biobak.quote: Keep in mind when I make these, that most of this is going to be reworked by the Biobak anyway.

biobak.summary: A community artist offered replacement textures; Kaze will evaluate them but defers final quality judgment to Biobak.
biobak.quote: If they put in enough work, I think they can make it better, so we’ll see.

key_stories.title: BLJ Crash Mystery
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovers that performing a BLJ in the new area consistently crashes the game. He recreates the bug on stream, confirms it isn’t triangle overflow, and concludes the custom BLJ routine enters an infinite loop.
key_stories.challenge: Players can still execute BLJ, but the hack hard-locks.
key_stories.process: Repeated in-engine tests, isolated to BLJ code, ruled out geometry issues.
key_stories.outcome: Needs explicit BLJ support; fix pending.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe it is gone. My fucking game crashed.

key_stories.title: Balancing a Diagonal Wall-Jump Section
key_stories.summary: A mandatory diagonal wall-jump felt ‘jank’ for casuals. Kaze experiments with alternate routes—small safety platform and long-jump path—while retaining a skilful speedrun shortcut.
key_stories.challenge: Make the jump readable and fun for both newbies and veterans.
key_stories.process: Iterative geometry edits, live play-testing, adding fallback platform.
key_stories.outcome: Section now offers three viable approaches with clear visual cues.
key_stories.key_quote: I don’t want the player to do a weird jump like that.

key_stories.title: Giving the Space Plantation its ‘Sauce’
key_stories.summary: The original space greenhouse looked bland. Kaze adds neon borders, directional signs, glowing crops and re-hues springs to give the level identity and reduce visual clutter.
key_stories.challenge: Level felt empty and visually noisy.
key_stories.process: Texture swaps, glow shaders, signposts, crop pattern experiments.
key_stories.outcome: Area now has distinct style; renamed ‘Cosmic Colony’.
key_stories.key_quote: Before the level felt like it had no sauce. And now it has a bit of sauce.

key_stories.title: Donation-Driven 30-Day Hack Idea
key_stories.summary: Kaze brainstorms a marathon stream where each $500–$1,000 donated adds another dev day, aiming to build a full hack live.
key_stories.challenge: Secure income while creating engaging content.
key_stories.process: Floats concept to chat, clarifies funds go to him, not charity.
key_stories.outcome: Idea parked for future; gauging community interest.
key_stories.key_quote: The more people donate, the higher quality the hack is going to be.
